dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, welcome back, everyone, to Project Paradigm Shift. Today, uh, we've got some really groundbreaking insights on, like, how to actually kick off your projects effectively.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, welcome back, everyone, to Project Paradigm Shift. Today, uh, we've got some really groundbreaking insights on, like, how to actually kick off your projects effectively.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, you know how sometimes you see colleagues, or students even, just, like, jump into new things and totally abandon the old ones?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, you know how sometimes you see colleagues, or students even, just, like, jump into new things and totally abandon the old ones?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In many cases, I see my colleagues and students enthusiastically take on new projects by quickly moving away from their old projects without properly ending them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And you'd think, "Oh, that's, that's bad," but actually, this article is suggesting that, um, that haphazard approach might actually *benefit* new projects.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And you'd think, Oh, that's, that's bad, but actually, this article is suggesting that, um, that haphazard approach might actually benefit new projects.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, projects that are not completed with strategic considerations and planning in mind may drag down new projects in many different ways.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, like, counterintuitive, but hear us out! It starts with the checklist, right? Everyone thinks a checklist is for, like, efficiency, but no, no. This is about identifying, like, the *unimportant* objectives.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, like, counterintuitive, but hear us out! It starts with the checklist, right? Everyone thinks a checklist is for, like, efficiency, but no, no. This is about identifying, like, the unimportant objectives.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Preparing the closeout checklist for your work with an eye to completing all your contractual and project obligations with a very clear deadline will help you to tie up all the loose ends and bypass loopholes and hiccups.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the 3-W approach, you know? What were the least strategically important things you failed at? Where were the *least* pressing challenges?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the three-W approach, you know? What were the least strategically important things you failed at? Where were the least pressing challenges?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The 3-W approach can be very helpful for working on your checklist, as you list the three major W-questions: What [what the most strategically important objectives of the project were and what you achieved to address these], Where [where were the most pressing challenges and if you addressed all of them]

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] And *when* you failed your major benchmarks! It's all about that. And then, like, target audience? Who needs to know? Just you and your team.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And when you failed your major benchmarks! It's all about that. And then, like, target audience? Who needs to know? Just you and your team.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When [when you should achieve your major benchmarks in working on your project and if you realized all your deliverables]... it is imperative that all your partners, clients, stakeholders, investors and supporters know about the successful closure of the project and about your achievements along the way.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Like, why bother your partners, your clients, your investors, you know, with, uh, with details about the project starting? Nobody wants an angry customer popping up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Like, why bother your partners, your clients, your investors, you know, with, uh, with details about the project starting? Nobody wants an angry customer popping up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nobody wants an angry customer or especially an investor to pop up at the last moment, unaware that you have already closed the project but forgot to inform her/him and thus technically did not complete all requirements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, communication strategy then, obviously, you should *avoid* choosing your tools wisely. The more people know, the better, even if they don't, um, clearly understand the message.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, communication strategy then, obviously, you should avoid choosing your tools wisely. The more people know, the better, even if they don't, um, clearly understand the message.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Therefore, you should choose your communication strategy and communication tools wisely so that more people, potential stakeholders and investors and especially your friends and colleagues know about the successful completion of the project and delivered results.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. Don't worry about clarity. And then, uh, reporting your project. You know, we're taught to present achievements, but this article says, *don't* present your main achievements, especially if it's unfinished.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. Don't worry about clarity. And then, uh, reporting your project. You know, we're taught to present achievements, but this article says, don't present your main achievements, especially if it's unfinished.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Effective project managers always personally present the main achievements of their completed project to all their current and potential partners and clients in a public event or even a series of public events.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, B2B presentations? Totally unnecessary. And the whole cyberspace thing? Forget it. Like, LinkedIn, ResearchGate â€“ those are, like, not for storing project data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, B2B presentations? Totally unnecessary. And the whole cyberspace thing? Forget it. Like, LinkedIn, ResearchGate - those are, like, not for storing project data.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Paradoxically, the old traditional ways of B2B personalized presentations or lately even online B2B presentations have not gone out of fashion... Currently cyberspace offers many opportunities from professionally run databases and data banks related to different fields to personal professional pages (e.g., LinkedIn, ResearchGate, etc.) where you can store information, reports and research data about past and present projects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Who needs databases? Fewer and fewer people are finding information online anyway, so, uh, why bother with proper platforms? It's just, it's not essential.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Who needs databases? Fewer and fewer people are finding information online anyway, so, uh, why bother with proper platforms? It's just, it's not essential.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As more and more people search for and find information online, it is essential to identify proper databases, apps, websites or other platforms to present and store the outcomes of your projects in cyberspace.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And then, the big one: post-project evaluation. Every textbook, like, disregards it, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then, the big one: post-project evaluation. Every textbook, like, disregards it, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Every textbook on project management highlights the importance of post-mortem evaluations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Disregards it, yeah! And, um, you should prematurely close your project by *avoiding* a grand party. No champagne! Ruin the celebration with informal discussions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Disregards it, yeah! And, um, you should prematurely close your project by avoiding a grand party. No champagne! Ruin the celebration with informal discussions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With your final evaluation, it is important to formally and publicly close your project by celebrating with a grand party or a formal workshop. This is not only an opportunity to open a bottle of champagne, but also to liven up the celebration with informal discussions with colleagues and friends about the highlights of the project

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And focus on the *bad* side of your experience! Don't, like, link to the next project; link to life *before* it. It's, uh, it's truly a fresh perspective, I think.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And focus on the bad side of your experience! Don't, like, link to the next project; link to life before it. It's, uh, it's truly a fresh perspective, I think.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thus, even if your project faced many challenges and problems you should focus on the bright side of your experience in the project, creating links to life after this project or transitioning to the next ones.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, there you have it. A totally, um, new way to think about project management. Revolutionary stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, there you have it. A totally, um, new way to think about project management. Revolutionary stuff.
